question:
(a) State three reasons to show that the earth is spherical

(b) Describe three effects of the revolution of the earth

(c) Calculate the noon altitude of the sun at the Tropic of Capricorn on June 21
answer:
(a) Three reasons to show that the earth is spherical include

(i) The circumnavigation of the earth

(ii) Sunrise and sunset

(iii) Eclipse of the moon.

(b) Three effects of the revolution of the earth include the follow

(i) It varies the length of day and night.

(ii) It causes seasons

(iii) It changes the altitude of the midday sun at differ times of the year

(i) Varying the length of day and night and seasons:- The earth is inclined at an angle of 66½ °N. In the Northern hemisphere in winter, during the month of December as we go northwards , hours and darkness increase. At artic circle (66½ °N) the sun never rises and there is darkness for the whole day around December 22nd. In summer around June, the conditions are reversed. Daylight increases as we go poleward. At the artic circle the sun never set at mid-summer (June 21st) and there is a complete 24 hour period of continuous daylight in the Southern hemisphere: the same process takes place except that the conditions are reversed. When it is summer in the Northern hemisphere the Southern hemisphere will experience winter.

Changes in the altitude of the midday sun: The sun is overhead vertically at the equator for two days each year. The days are March 21st and September 23rd. These two days are called Equinoxes (meaning equal days any nights). Because of these two days, all parts of the world will experience equal days and equal nights. After the March equinox, the sun appears to move northward and vertically overhead at the Tropic of Cancer (23½°N) around June 21st. This is known as June or summer solstice (when the Northern Hemisphere will have its longest day shortest nights). By December 22nd, the sun will be overhead at the tropic or capricorn (23½ºS) called December or winter solstice, i.e when the Southern Hemisphere has its longest day and shortest night

(c) To calculate the noon altitude of the sun at the Tropic of capricorn on June 21. The sun is overhead at the Tropic of capricorn i.e, 23½°S. Angle at right angle = 90° since the angle at the Tropic of capricorn is 23½°S. The noon altitude on June 21 of the sun is 90° - 23½ºS = 66½

question:

(ii) Both are measured in degrees

(iii) Both are angular distance of a point on the earth's surf

(ii) Lines of latitude are used to calculate distance between one place to another
(iii) Lines of latitude cannot be used to calculate local time.
(iv) The latitudinal extent of the globe is from 90°N and 90°S 

- Lines of longitude run from North to South between one place and another.
- Lines of longitude cannot be used to calculate distance between one place and another
- Lines of longitude are used in calculating local time.
- The longitudinal extent of the globe is from 180° E to 180°W

question:
(a) Describe the characteristics of any two of the following types of landforms
(i) delta
(ii) atoll
(iii) caldera

(b) Explain with the aid of diagrams the mode of formation of each of the landforms you have chosen
answer:
(a)(i) The characteristics of a delta include:

(i) The branching of rivers into channels called distributaries

(ii) Large deposits of weathered materials

(iii) It is formed at the mouth of rivers

(iv) It takes up the shape of a fan

(b) The r of formation of a delta is influenced by the following factors; 

(i) Active vertical and lateral erosion in the upper course of the river to provide extensive sediments to be deposited as deltas

(ii) The coast should be sheltered or tic',

(iii) The sea adjoining the delta should be shallow or else the load will disappear in the deep waters

(iv), Absence of lakes in the river course to filter off the sediments

(v) Absence of strong current running at right angles to the mouth so as not to wash away sediments 

(b)(i) Characteristics of caldera:

(i) It is formed from volcanic activities

(ii) It is a depression on volcano cones with steep sides

(iii) Depression of magma gives rise to caldera

(iv) It may contain water called caldera lake. Caldera is formed when composite volcano explodes violently, its top is blown off and disintegrates into a mass of rocks and ashes, leaving the crater greatly enlarged. The huge crater-like depression is coiled caldera. It can also be formed through subsidence. The depression may result in accumulation of water to form caldera lake

question:
(a) Name three types of mountains and give a good example of each

(b) Describe the process of formation of any type of mountains

(c) In what four ways are mountains of great importance to man?.
answer:
(a) Three types of mountains are:

(i) Block mountain e.g the Hunstruck mt. of Germany

(ii) Fold mountain e.g the Himalayas

(iii) Volcanic mountain, e.g Fuji mountain of Japan

(b) Mode of formation of Fold mountains

(i) Folding is caused by large stale h Drizontal earth movement

(ii) Stresses, caused by expansion or contraction of some parts of the earth, are set up in the earth's crust

(iii) Such stresses subject the reeks to compressive forces

(iv) The compressive forces produce wrinkling or folding of the earth's crust

(v) The upfold of the wrinkles are called anticlines while the downfold are synclines.

(c) Four ways in which mountains are of great importance to man; 

(i) High  mountain can result in the formation of rainfall i.e relief rainfall

(ii) Mountain serves as the source or origin of all rivers

(iii) Mountains are rich sources of minerals Stones found in mountains can be quarried for building construction

question:
(a)(i) Name two distinct types of soil erosion
(ii) Locate an area where each type is most common

(b) Outline any three factors that have been responsible for any one of the types of soil erosion named above

(c) Describe any three measures being taken to solve the problem of soil erosion in any one of the areas.
answer:
(a)(i) Two types of soil erosion are;

(i) Water erosion and Wind erosion

(ii) The area where water erosion is most common is moist humid area of the tropic (i.e rainforest areas), while wind erosion is common in the arid and semi arid areas especially in the desert

(b) Three factors responsible for water erosion are

(i) Excessive rainfall

(ii) Impervious nature of underlying rock

(iii) Increase in declivity (slope). The greater the slope, the greater the velocity and degree of erosion.

(c) Three measures being taken to solve the problem of soil erosion in tropical area of the world are:

(i) Contour ploughing. This involves the making of ridges across the slope to reduce surface run off

(ii) Strip cropping: In slopy areas, strip cropping is done to also reduce the surface run off of the water

(iii) Proper channelisation. This involves the construction of gutters to channel away the large volume of water caused by erosion

question:
Explain the factors responsible for the very high population density in the

(a) North-East of USA

(b) Indus and Ganges deltas.
answer:
(a) Factors responsible for the very high population density in North - East of USA are:

(i) Presence of great deposits of iron and coal

(ii) Location of many industries

(iii) Favourable climate conducive for human habitation

(iv)Availability of jobs which make population to increase

(iv) Heavy trading of manufactured goods within and outside the industrial zone of USA.

(b) Factors which favour the high population density in the Indus and Ganges deltas

(i) Abundance of rainfall which ensures smooth agricultural activities

(ii) The soils are very fertile

(iii) Intensive agricultural activities attract people to the area (they grow 2-3 crops in a year)

(iv) Favourable climate conducive for intensive farming.

question: Show the similarities and differences between road and railway as major means of transportation
answer:
(a) Similarities between road and railway as major means of transportation are

(i) Both road and railway are located on land

(ii) Both are relatively cheap

(iii) Both can be used to transport people and goods from one place to another

(b) Differences between transportation by road and railway 

Transportation by Road Transportation by rail

(1) Provides door-to-door service
(2) It can only cover short distances
(3) Carries mainly passengers
(4) Less expensive to construct and maintain
(5) It serves mainly residential areas 

- Does not provide door-to-door service
- It can cover very long distances
- Carries mainly goods especially agricultural and mineral products
- More expensive to construct and maintain 
- It serves mainly industrial and agricultural areas

question:
Explain any six factors each which have favoured the development of any two of the following industries:

(a) Iron and steel industry in the Ruhr region

(b) Ship building in Japan

(c) Chemical industry in eastern United States of America

(d) Textile industries in Great Britain
answer:
(a) Six factors which have favoured the development of Iron and Steel industry in the Ruhr region

(i) Availability of coal which provides cheap source of coke for processing iron ore

(ii) Availability of Iron ore

(iii) Presence of Rhine which is one of the most navigable rivers in Europe, enables raw materials and goods to be moved between North Sea and Ruhr region

(iv) Good network of excellent roads linking Rhine valley with the rest of West Germany

(v) Abundance of soft, clear water

(vi) By-products of Iron and steel industry leads to the development of chemical industries

(b) Six factors which have favoured the development of Textile industries in Great Britain; 

(i) Availability of raw materials, e.g cotton, wool, silk and linen etc.

(ii) Presence of coal which makes it possible for steam power to replace water power

(iii) Abundance of soft water which is essential to removing the grease from wool before it is spun

(iv) Abundance of skilled labour

(v) Availability of large market

(vi) Well developed centres and ports for the export of textile.

question:
(a) With the aid of appropriate diagrams, describe the distinguishing characteristics of any three types of urban settlements

(b) Discs any four problems of urbanization
answer:
Three types of urban settlement include:
(i) Cities
(ii) Conurbation
(iii) Megalopolis

(i) City: A city is made up of large towns with great( number of people and services. In a city there are towns which combined together to function as one

(ii) Conurbation: Is made up of two or more towns join E together through growth but which may still retain thE identities. These two towns are separated from eac other but through expansion or growth have joined together. But despite this, they still retain their identities

(iii) Megalopolis: This is the largest of tl-urban settlements and includes the joining of man cities to form an extensive urban area. 

(b) Four problems of urbanization include:

(i) Inadequate transport facilities. Increase in the number of people in the urban area often leads to problem of transportation

(ii) Overuse and deterioration of available social services. Most of the social services available,. e.g electricity, stadium, school, hospital are overused and this leads to their deterioration

(iii) There is an aggravated problem of unemployment and underemployment in the cities as well as reduce labour force in the rural areas

(iv) There is the problem of undue increase in human and vehicular traffic.

question:
(a) With specific examples give four reasons why countries exchange goods and services

(b) Account for the low volume of trade between Nigeria and the rest of Africa.
answer:
(a) Four reasons why countries exchange goods and services

(i) Natural resources; Natural resources of the world are unevenly distributed e.g Nigeria's petroleum is sold to Brazil in exchange for vehicles, sugar and communication equipment.

(ii) Degree of Industrial Development; Due to high technical knowledge and expertise which a country has in the production of goods and electronic equipment than other countries e.g Japan specialises in the production of electronic equipment

(iii) Some crops are more suited to certain climatic condition. Crops like cocoa, cotton, etc, grow in tropical regions while crops like wheat, barley and oats grow well in temperate regions

(iv) Geographical Situation; Some countries have situations which enable them to take part in trade between contrasting economies e.g Singapore handles much of South East Asia's trade

(b) Reasons for low volume of trade between Nigeria and the rest of Africa are

(i) African countries produce goods which are very similar, leaving little or no room for exchange

(ii) Nigerians have a high taste for imported goods from foreign countries. These goods are not produced by other African countries

(iii) Nigeria's foreign exchange earnings from African countries is very low - about 20%

(iv) Prices of goods offered by African countries are usually very low compared with foreign countries

(v) African countries demand for very low quantity of goods unlike foreign countries.

answer:
(b) Rubber is produced or extracted from the tre( a process called tapping. Early in the morning  rubber farmer goes to tap his rubber trees by making a cut on them. question:

(i) Inland fishing- not very popular and it is only done in Rivers Orange and Great Fish River

(ii) Offshore fishing - Done along the entire coast of South Africa and also in deep seas i.e Atlantic and Indian oceans. Some of the fishing ports are port Elizabeth, Durban, East London.

(b) Methods of fishing. On a large scale the method of fishing involves-the use of  trawlers especially in the oceans

(c) Major type of fish caught. These include mackerel, herring, salmon, had etc.

(d) Preparation and marketing of fish. Fish caught are cleaned, refrigerated in cold stores and can be exp as raw fish. It can also be processed into usable canfish e.g sardines which are later consumed locally or exported 

(e) Fishing is very important for the following reasons:

(i) It provides rich source of protein for the people

(ii) Its exportation provides foreign exchange earning for the country

(iii) It also provides jobs for many people

(iv) It has resulted in the establishment of fish processing industries.

(iv) The cattle are subjected to love of feeding

(c) Fruit farming in South Africa

(i) Fruit farming is made possible as a result of favourable climate and this includes bright and sunny weather, rainfall of 500- 700mm and temperature of 28°C

(ii) Availability of fertile valleys where animal soil ex
